chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of knee pain
chapter.summary: Covers the assessment of people presenting with knee pain.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 6 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When do I arrange admission for a person with knee pain?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Admit or refer for immediate specialist assessment:
    • If septic arthritis is suspected or cannot be excluded.
    • If a slipped capital femoral epiphysis is suspected.
    • If osteonecrosis is suspected.
    • If a fracture cannot be excluded.
    • If there is any evidence of neurovascular damage following trauma (including loss of sensation or weakness in the lower leg or foot, absence or asymmetry of pedal pulses, or compartment syndrome).
    • If quadriceps or patellar tendon rupture is suspected.
    • If first-time traumatic patellar dislocation is suspected, or a recurrent dislocation is associated with moderate or severe swelling.
    • If there is severe soft tissue injury with gross instability.
      • Discuss with a specialist as there may be an appropriate alternative available locally (see below).
  • Consider admission or referral for immediate assessment:
    • If a child presents with a limp, depending on clinical features - see the CKS topic Acute childhood limp for detailed guidance.
    • If Henoch-Schönlein purpura is suspected - seek specialist advice.
  • Depending on local arrangements, refer to an accident and emergency department, fracture clinic or acute knee clinic:
    • If a significant soft tissue injury is suspected in a person with acute knee pain following trauma, due to:
      • A sensation of a 'pop' or 'snap'.
      • Rapid swelling.
      • Inability to complete the activity.
      • Instability.
      • Locking.
      • Giving way.
    • If unsure of the appropriate referral pathway, seek specialist advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Admit or refer for immediate assessment
  • If septic arthritis is suspected.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in joint UK guidelines for the management of a hot, swollen joint in adults [Mathews, 2006].
  • If slipped capital femoral epiphysis is suspected.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion by CKS reviewers.
  • If osteonecrosis is suspected.
    • In the absence of published evidence, this recommendation is based on expert opinion by CKS reviewers; reasons for immediate referral are to confirm the diagnosis and exclude other serious causes of sudden, severe pain.
  • If fracture, significant soft tissue injury or quadriceps/patellar tendon rupture is suspected.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in an NHS Scotland referral and management pathway [NHS Scotland, 2013] and local NHS pathways [NHS Mansfield and Ashfield CCG, 2015; Harrogate and Rural District CCG, 2017].
  • If there is evidence of neurovascular damage.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Fanelli, 2011] and a BMJ Best Practice review [BMJ Best Practice, 2016a].
  • If first-time traumatic patellar dislocation suspected.
    • This recommendation is pragmatic as investigations to assess for internal injury such as fracture, and initial immobilisation are generally recommended [Hong, 2014]. If patellar dislocation has not reduced spontaneously, reduction in an emergency department is recommended [Simon, 2014]. 
  • If patellar dislocation occurs in a person with recurrent dislocation, and is associated with moderate or severe swelling.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Calmbach and Hutchens, 2003a].
  • If Henoch-Schönlein purpura is suspected.
    • This recommendation is based on expert opinion about the prognosis and risk of complication in review articles [Lim et al, 2009; Reamy et al, 2009] and the need to rule out other serious causes in children presenting with a purpuric rash [Thomas, 2016].  
Consider admission or referral for immediate assessment
  • If a child presents with a limp.
    • This topic is covered in detail in the CKS topic Acute childhood limp.
Consider whether direct referral to an appropriate service is available locally
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion from CKS reviewers and local NHS knee pain pathways indicating the availability of acute knee pain services in some areas that provide urgent assessment of traumatic knee injuries not suspected to be fractures.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When do I refer a person with knee pain?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer urgently (to be seen within 2 weeks of referral) to an appropriate specialist if a tumour is suspected.
  • Refer any person with suspected persistent synovitis of undetermined cause to a rheumatologist to assess for inflammatory polyarthritis.
    • Refer urgently (usually to be seen within 2 weeks) if any of the following are present:
      • The small joints of the hand or feet are affected.
      • More than one joint is affected.
      • There has been a delay of 3 months or longer between symptom onset and seeking medical help.
    • Refer urgently to a paediatric rheumatologist if a child or young person presents with suspected juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
  • Refer a person to an orthopaedic surgeon:
    • If they present with chronic (present for over a month) knee pain (if acute/sub-acute presentation, urgent referral of admission may be recommended), associated with any of the following:
      • A history of significant injury (feeling of pop/snap, rapid swelling, inability to complete activity).
      • True locking.
      • True giving way.
      • Effusion/swelling.
      • Joint line pain tenderness.
    • If any of the following conditions are suspected:
      • Recurrent patellar dislocation.
      • Osteochondritis dissecans.
      • Bipartite patella, if troublesome.
      • Fat pad inflammation/impingement.
    • Note that direct access to MRI scan may be available depending on local arrangements, for people with knee pain meeting locally-defined criteria.
  • Provided there are no indications for direct referral to emergency services or to a specialist, refer a person to a physiotherapist:
    • If they have chronic knee pain (present for over 1 month).
      • If there is failure to improve within 3 months of commencing physiotherapy, refer to an orthopaedic surgeon.
    • If they have acute knee pain.
      • Initial management in primary care is also an option for these people.
      • If there is failure to improve within 4-6 weeks of commencing physiotherapy, refer to an orthopaedic surgeon.
    • If they have patellofemoral pain syndrome, particularly if not improved after 6 weeks of conservative management.
    • If they have patellar subluxation.
  • Refer to an appropriate specialist if complex regional pain syndrome is suspected for confirmation of diagnosis and to rule out other causes.
    • This may be to an orthopaedic surgeon if pain is secondary to trauma/surgery, or to an appropriate secondary care physician such as a rheumatologist if there was no preceding trauma.
    • If complex regional pain syndrome is confirmed, referral to a pain specialist is recommended in all but very mild cases.
  • If the diagnosis is uncertain, consider referring to an appropriate specialist (for example a rheumatologist, orthopaedic surgeon, sports physician, or other musculoskeletal specialist).
  • For when to refer to a specialist for other conditions, see the CKS topics on:
    • Osteoarthritis.
    • Pre-patellar bursitis.
    • Gout.
    • Baker's cyst.
    • Osgood-Schlatter disease.
    • Acute childhood limp.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Refer urgently if a tumour is suspected
  • This recommendation is in line with the National Collaborating Centre for Cancer and National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Suspected cancer: recognition and referral guidelines [National Collaborating Centre for Cancer, 2015].
Refer urgently if persistent synovitis (inflammatory polyarthritis) is suspected
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE guideline Rheumatoid arthritis in adults: management [NICE, 2015b] and guidelines on the diagnosis and management of juvenile idiopathic arthritis by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners [RACGP, 2009].
Other referral recommendations
  • The recommendation to refer to an orthopaedic surgeon if a person presents with chronic knee pain associated with features such as locking or previous significant injury is based on expert opinion in a management pathway produced by NHS Scotland [NHS Scotland, 2013].
  • The recommendation to refer to an orthopaedic surgeon if a person has suspected recurrent patellar dislocation, osteochondritis dissecans, bipartite patella (if troublesome) or fat pad inflammation/impingement is based on expert opinion in a review article [Houghton, 2007], BMJ Best Practice review [BMJ Best Practice, 2016d] and textbooks [Bulstrode, 2011; Simon, 2014].
  • The recommendation on referral to a physiotherapist is based on expert opinion in a management pathway produced by NHS Scotland [NHS Scotland, 2013] and review articles on patellofemoral pain [Houghton, 2007; Crossley, 2016].
  • The recommendation to refer patients with suspected complex regional pain syndrome to an appropriate specialist is in line with the Royal College of Physicians (RCP) guideline Complex regional pain syndrome in adults [Royal College of Physicans, 2012].
  • The recommendation to consider referring to an appropriate specialist if the diagnosis is uncertain is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice. An alternative management option may be watchful waiting, depending on the circumstances and provided there are no flags.
